Key Arguments: The bill does not clearly define who determines the truth.
It infringes on individuals' rights to research and share their beliefs.
Misinformation and disinformation are incorrectly lumped together.
Lack of independent oversight is concerning.
The bill is compared to totalitarian practices like book burning.
Free speech is essential to democracy, and this bill threatens it.
The bill could erode the right to protest, a fundamental democratic right.
The example of harmful content used in the bill is flawed and not applicable to Australia.
The bill could lead to blacklisting authors, harming freedom of speech.
There is a concern about unequal persecution and lack of accountability for governments and institutions.
The bill could drive information sharing underground and force services to leave Australia.
It may lead to self-censorship, harming freedom of expression.
Notable Quotes: I equate the powers in this new bill to book burning under Totalitarian, fascist and dictator government.
Free speech is the bedrock of democracy. Without it you have a dictatorship.
This bill will trample an individuals right to research and share what they believe to be true.
Policing of digital platforms, content and search engines will drive the sharing of information underground.
